content.description: Grab the jug at head height and haul yourself onto the boulder. Not much available for footholds, but the friction is quite good for smearing.
content.location: Around the corner from Salad, facing the road.

content.description: Same as Crouton Salad, but work left to avoid the prominent flake.

Best problem on the boulder!

Don’t let the size of this boulder fool you. This route has two moves but they’re big moves. 

 Don’t let the grade of this boulder fool you. This route has some powerful moves.

 Not sure who did the FA or what the name/grade is. There was chalk on the second hold and shoe rubber on the start hold I used. I assume I did the low start (Matched - see photo.) Also the second hold broke and is less of a bucket now.
content.location: North side of the Appetizer Boulder

content.description: Start from crimps at chest height, work straight up. Look for a V-shaped slot for a starting foot. The crux is generously provided by the tree getting right up in your face, hence the name.
content.protection: It helps to have someone to hold the branch out of the way.
content.location: On the east face of Appetizer, to the right of Soup du Jour.

content.description: Start with left foot on the large edge, and right hand in the pocket or palm press just beneath it. Work straight up to the prominent flake. (That's the crouton.)

A small freestanding boulder hosting a variety of slabby warmup problems. The short approach, good landing, and low difficulty make this a great choice for someone climbing outside for the first time.  

  Because of the angle and rock texture, some of the climbs may actually feel easier barefoot than with modern climbing shoes.
